Statement: I lost a lot of weight lately. I haven't been eating well because I'm too busy.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): When I have many things to do, I think that eating will impede my work and is wasting too much time.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Maybe not eating enough will make me more tired, and I will be less efficient at my work.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I can eat healthy foods that does not take too long to eat. This way I can be efficient and maintain my weight.

Statement: I lost a lot of weight lately. I haven't been eating well because I'm too busy.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): When I have a lot of things to finish, I loose my appetite and often forgets to eat.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Perhaps I am hungry but the stress just takes over and I can't feel it.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I can set a regular schedule dedicated for meals and stay healthy that way.

Statement: I lost a lot of weight lately. I haven't been eating regularly because I'm too busy.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I don't need to eat because I don't feel hungry.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Maybe I am hungry but I just don't feel it.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I will just force myself to eat even when I don't want to.

Statement: I gained a lot of weight recently because I can't control what to eat. I always feel hungry and need to eat something.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): When there is something that I want to eat, I often tell myself that it probably isn't that much calories and I can excercise later, but I never do that.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): How am I sure that the food I eat are not high calorie? Did I check the label before eating it or am I just deceiving myself?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I will check the labels next time before I eat something, but that probably won't stop me from eating it.

Statement: I gained a lot of weight recently. I feel so fat right now.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I am very stressed lately and I find eating as the only way to relieve that.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Does eating more actually relive my stress? Could there be other ways to relax?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I can try to find another way to deal with stress that does not involve excessive eating, or eat something healthier.

Statement: I gained a lot of weight recently because I'm too lazy to move and I love eating junk food. They are very good and don't like to eat other things.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It takes too much effort to excercise and I will feel too tired after it. Junk foods are cheap and tasty so I like them.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Does excercising really take that much effort? I might have chose the wrong excercises to do. Could there be other food that are also tasty and cheap?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I will start with some easier excerise and watch some food reviews to find tasty and good food.

Statement: I feel a lot of pressure recently. I'm just overwhelmed by all the tasks that I have to finish.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): There are too many deadlines to catch and I can't imagine how bad I'm gonna look if I don't make them on time.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Will I actually be judged if I miss a deadline or two? Maybe I shouldn't be too worried right now because there is still time.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I don't need to feel too much pressure because I can probably finish everything on time and it wouldn't be the end of my life if I don't. Everyone makes mistakes.

Statement: I feel a lot of pressure recently and I don't know what to do. I think I overestimated what I can complete.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): There are too many deadlines to catch and I can't imagine how bad I'm gonna look if I don't make them on time.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Will I actually be judged if I miss a deadline or two? Maybe I shouldn't be too worried right now because there is still time.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I still can't imagine if I would be fine. I must work even harder.

Statement: I am very sad these days because I don't have any friends in the city I just I moved to and I can't make any.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): People here must already have established friends groups so they won't easily accept me. I can't just walk up to random people and meet them.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Are there really no one that wants new friends at this place? Maybe there are newcomers like me or some people are just more welcoming. Is walking up to random people the only way to make friends?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): There are many ways to make new friends. I can go on social media and find people with the same hobbies.

Statement: I am very sad these days because I don't have any friends in the city I just I moved to and I can't make any.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): People here must already have established friends groups so they won't easily accept me. I can't just walk up to random people and meet them.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Are there really no one that wants new friends at this place? Maybe there are newcomers like me or some people are just more welcoming. Is walking up to random people the only way to make friends?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I am not confident in meeting new people. Maybe I will just stay this way and just live with it.

Statement: I feel very depressed. I can't do anything.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I don't know why but I'm just depressed.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): I really can't think of any reasons.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): It's pobably not a big deal. I will stay depressed.

Statement: I always forget to take my medications. I don't feel its effect anyway.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): After the take the medications, I don't feel like I'm getting better, so I don't remember taking it. Will it actually help me?
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): How do I know that the medications doesn't work? Is feeling the correct way to assess its effectiveness?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): The medications are probably working and it just takes more time to feel the effect. Maybe me not taking it regularly is acutally the reason that its not working.

Statement: I don't want to take any medications. I don't know what they would do to me.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I don't know what's in the pills. Are they really helping me? I think the doctors are making me take it for no good reason. It might actually be harmful for me.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Have I done any research about the content of the pills? Is there any reason that the doctor does not want to help me?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I should trust the doctors and take the medications on time. I can also do some research my self and consult more professionals.

Statement: I don't want to take any medications. I don't trust them.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I've heard that doctors just want to sell you the pills. They don't really care if I get better. I don't trust what they give me.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): I don't know how I can prove that that the medications work. Most people don't get better anyways.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I will just get better by myself. Taking the medication is a pain.

Statement: I take medications when I feel like it. I skip some days if I'm feeling alright.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I might take some when I feel down. Why would I take it when I feel good?
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): How do I know that the medications will have the same effect if I don't take it as prescribed.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Since I haven't tried to take it regularly, I should try it and then decide whether I need a different treatment.

Dimension: Participating primary and mental health care
Statement: I did not see my therapist consistently. I don't think they help me.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I felt better for a day or two and then became stressed out again. I think going to these sessions only have a shorterm effect and they are not real.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Perhaps the effect is not shorterm and I just have wait it out. Maybe other people can see that I got better but I don't feel the difference as much.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): The shorterm effect could be important for me too, and the long term effect is just happening slowly and I need more time to see it.

Dimension: Participating primary and mental health care
Statement: I did not see my therapist consistently. I don't think they help me.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Therapists just say things that I want to hear at the moment. They don't care if it treats me.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): I think seeing them consistently is not gonna help me.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I don't want to do these sessions anymore.

Dimension: Participating primary and mental health care
Statement: I'm way too busy and stressed out lately, I have no time to see my therapist. There's just too many things on top of my mind.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): When I'm stressed I think going to therapist is going to waste too much of my time. I could be using this time to do more things.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Maybe going to therapist is not a waste of time. It might not even take that long. I can still finish other things.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Going to therapist regularly can help my stress. I might become more efficient and feel better.

Dimension: Participating primary and mental health care
Statement: I always forget to schedule an appointment with my doctor. I don't feel like its necessary at this point.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I think its a hassle to have to go to doctor's. So I always try to do it later and ends up never doing it.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Scheduling an appointment might not be that hard. There could be other ways to setup a regular schedule and have someone remind me.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I can express my need to the doctor and we might be able to setup something that is easy for me and also remind me beforehand.

Dimension: Participating primary and mental health care
Statement: I always forget to schedule an appointment with my doctor. I don't feel like its necessary at this point.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I think its a hassle to have to go to doctor's. So I always try to do it later and ends up never doing it.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Scheduling an appointment might not be that hard. There could be other ways to setup a regular schedule and have someone remind me.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I guess making an appoinment isn't that much trouble, but I still don't want to go.

Statement: I don't organize my house that often. I'm too lazy to do it.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I piled too much things up and now it takes a lot of effort to organize them all. So I always tell myself that I will do it next week.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Why did I pile things up in the first place? Do I have to organize them all at once?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I can organize thing at small batches. That way it doesn't take too much effort or time. I can also not add to the pile.

Statement: I can't be bothered to clean my house. It's not like that's gonna kill me.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I don't know why I need to clean my house. I think I can lively normally in a messy room.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Are there some advantages to have a clean room? Are there troubles I'm facing for not cleaning it?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I did enjoy the house clean at first. A cleaner room will cause less bugs or bacteria to form. I can find things more easily in a clean house.

Statement: I want to clean my apartment once a week, but I'm hardly doing it.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Sometimes I tell myself that the apartment looks alright and I can just do it the week after, but it gets a whole lot messier and I don't know where to begin the next week and end up not doing it.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is it ok to not do it because it doesn't look messy? Would it be easier for me overall just to do it regularly?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I still don't think I can do it regulalry. I can't find the motivation to do it when it doesn't look that bad.

Statement: I awlays pile my trash up. I think it just doesn't bother me.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I find nothing wrong with piling up trash. I can eventually take it out when it start to bother me too much.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Would it bother other people that come visit me? Doesn't it consistently annoys me, even just a little? Is there any specific and logical reason that I pile up trash?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Even if it doesn't bother me too much, it might bother someone else, and not piling trash isn't that hard to do so I might try something first.

Statement: I don't like to talk to other people. I always start an argument.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I tend to argue with people if they don't agrree with me. So after getting angry many times I just stop talking to other people.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): People don't agree with each other all the time and they still talk. Why did I heat the conversation anyways?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Even if I do argue, we can have an intelligent discussion and maintain our good relations. And I also don't need to argue with everything I disagree with.

Statement: I find it very tiring to talk to other people. I have to care about what they think.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I'm afraid people will get mad at me for something I say. So I have to be very careful with what i say and that put a lot of stress in my mind.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Will people get mad that easily? Is it really my fault that people gets mad at what I say? Can I find other people to talk to?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I can talk to friends that I know I won't easily offend, or someone who is comfortable with me. Even if I say something wrong, I can just correct my wording or apologize.

Statement: I don't have anyone to talk to. No one really finds me to talk.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): If no one want to talk to me, then I'm fine that way.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): There really nothing I can do.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I guess I just have to live like this.

Statement: I don't know what to talk about with others, so I just don't talk to anyone.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I must always have something profound or interesting to say, or else I think other people will get bored and stop being friends with me.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is every conversation meant to be profound or interesting? Aren't casual and light-hearted exchanges about non-exciting daily lives also valuable for building relationships?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): It's okay to engage in simple, casual conversations. These moments can also strengthen bonds and create a comfortable space for everyone.

Statement: I don't know what to talk about with others, so I just don't talk to anyone.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I must always have something profound or interesting to say, or else I think other people will get bored and stop being friends with me.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): There is no way around that. I'm just not an interesting person.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Maybe not talking to anyone is ok for me.

Statement: I'm afraid I might say something out of place in a conversation, that's why I never start a conversation.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I like to say whatever's on top of my head, and people might not like that. If I don't start the conversation, then I'm less likely to talk about something thats wrong for the current context.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is there any reason that saying something out of place is unacceptable? Do others not talk about things that are out of place?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): It's ok to start a conversation and talk about something I'm thinking. Even if I did say something wrong, others might not even be concerned about it.

Statement: I find it hard to express my feelings. I don't reall express my feelings to anyone honestly.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I worry that if I show my true feelings, people will judge me or think less of me. I believe that keeping my emotions to myself is safer and prevents me from being vulnerable to others' opinions or potential rejection.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is there evidence that expressing my feelings will always lead to negative judgments or rejection? Could there be benefits to opening up that I'm not considering, like deepening relationships or receiving support?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Expressing my feelings honestly might actually lead to stronger, more authentic connections with others. Everyone has vulnerabilities, and sharing mine could encourage others to open up too, leading to mutual understanding and support.

Statement: I find it hard to express my feelings. I don't reall express my feelings to anyone honestly.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I don't have that much emotions anyways.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is there evidence that expressing my feelings will always lead to negative judgments or rejection? Could there be benefits to opening up that I'm not considering, like deepening relationships or receiving support?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Still, I don't feel the need to express my feelings.

Statement: I want to express my feelings to other people but I don't know how to do it correctly.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I'm afraid that if I try to express my feelings, I'll do it wrong and people will misunderstand me or get upset. This fear makes me hold back, even when I really want to share what's on my mind.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is there a perfect way to express feelings, or is it more about the effort and intention behind the communication? Could my fear of doing it wrong be preventing me from the opportunity to learn and improve through practice?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Expressing feelings is a skill that improves with practice and there's no single right way to do it. It's important to be genuine and considerate in my approach.

Statement: I don't express my feelings to others because I think that will make me vulnerable. I want to portray myself as a strong individual.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I believe showing my feelings to others exposes me to potential harm or exploitation. I fear that vulnerability is a weakness that others might use against me, leading me to keep my emotions closely guarded.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is vulnerability truly a weakness, or can it be a strength that leads to closer, more authentic relationships? Have there been instances where others' openness has led me to respect and connect with them more deeply?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Being vulnerable by expressing my feelings can actually strengthen relationships and build trust. It shows I'm human and allows others to relate to me on a deeper level. Embracing vulnerability can be empowering and lead to greater emotional support and connections.

Statement: I don't see the reason to express my feelings to others. I'm fine keeping them to myself.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I believe that keeping my feelings to myself is the best way to maintain control and avoid unnecessary complications. Sharing my emotions seems like it would only lead to judgment or discomfort.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could there be benefits to sharing my feelings that I'm overlooking, such as deepening connections or gaining different perspectives? Might keeping everything to myself limit the support and understanding I could receive from others?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Expressing my feelings isn't just about seeking help or unloading. It's also about allowing others to understand me better and fostering mutual trust. It can lead to more meaningful relationships and a stronger support network.

Statement: When making decisions, I don't usually put safety as a concern. There are others things that I think about first and then I often ignore safety.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I tend to believe that prioritizing safety makes decisions less effective or limits opportunities. I might think that being overly cautious is a sign of weakness or indecisiveness.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is it possible that integrating safety into decision-making can actually lead to more sustainable and positive outcomes? Could overlooking safety lead to unnecessary risks that might undermine my goals?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Considering safety as an integral part of decision making doesn't mean being fearful or overly cautious. It means being responsible and forward-thinking. Balancing safety with other factors can lead to more robust and reliable outcomes.

Statement: I would like to be safe, but I'm not thinking about it that often when making decisions. It's just not something that I would always remember to consider.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I think it's because my life so far has been very safe. I rarely had to worry about my safety and everything worked out fine, so I always consider other things first.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could neglecting safety actually lead to consequences that are dangerous? Might there be a way to incorporate safety without significantly hindering my decision-making process?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Integrating safety into my decisions can be a form of self-care and long-term planning. It's about finding a balance that doesn't compromise my well-being for short-term gains. This approach can lead to more sustainable and fulfilling outcomes.

Statement: I'm always worried about my personal safety and I miss a lot of opportunities because of it.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I often think that any risk, no matter how small, is not worth taking, leading me to avoid new experiences or opportunities. This excessive concern for safety makes me believe that staying in my comfort zone is the only way to protect myself.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is my level of worry about safety in proportion to the actual risks involved? Are there opportunities I've missed that had manageable risks or where precautions could have been effectively employed?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Assessing risks more objectively and recognizing that some level of risk is inherent to growth can help me make more balanced decisions. Taking calculated risks, with appropriate safety measures in place, can lead to personal growth and new experiences without compromising my well-being.

Statement: I'm always worried about my personal safety and I miss a lot of opportunities because of it.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It's always good to be safe.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Why would other people not put their safety first?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I guess I could open myself to a little more risks.

Statement: I take a lot of risk. I like the thrill.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I often equate taking risks with excitement and living life to the fullest, thinking that without constant high-risk challenges, life would be dull. This mindset can lead me to underestimate or ignore potential consequences.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is the thrill I seek from high-risk situations truly worth the potential outcomes? Could there be other ways to find excitement and fulfillment that don't compromise my safety or well-being?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Seeking excitement and challenge is important, but I can find a balance that doesn't put me at unnecessary risk. There are ways to pursue adventure and growth within safer boundaries, ensuring that I enjoy thrilling experiences without endangering myself or others.

Statement: I feel like taking risk is a necessary part of everyone's life, but sometimes I get frustrated because I cannot control the outcome.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I believe that taking risks is essential for growth, yet it's scary when things don't go as planned. It sometimes feels like, despite my best efforts, the results are out of my hands.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is it possible to embrace the uncertainty that comes with risk without feeling overwhelmed by it? How can I differentiate between taking calculated risks and leaving too much to chance?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Recognizing that some level of uncertainty is inherent in risk-taking, I can focus on making informed decisions. This involves weighing the potential benefits against the risks and accepting that not all outcomes are within my control, but that's part of the growth process.

Statement: I take no risks and that often blocked me to do many important things.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I tend to avoid risks at all costs, convinced that this is the safest way to live. This mindset, however, seems to prevent me from pursuing opportunities that could be important or beneficial.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could my aversion to risk be limiting my potential more than protecting me? What important experiences or growth opportunities might I be missing out on due to this cautious approach?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Finding a middle ground where I can cautiously evaluate and take on manageable risks could open up new avenues for growth. It's about learning to assess situations more strategically, allowing me to embrace opportunities while still being mindful of potential downsides.

Dimension: Following regular schedule for bedtime & sleeping enough
Statement: My sleeping schedule is all over the place. I have trouble falling alseep and waking up.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I'm stuck with this erratic sleeping pattern, and it feels like no matter what I try, I can't get into a proper rhythm. It's as if my body just won't cooperate, leaving me feeling helpless.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is this situation truly fixed, or might there be strategies and habits I haven't explored yet? Have I considered all possible factors that could be influencing my sleep, from environment to routine?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Adjusting my sleep schedule might require a combination of tactics, from setting a consistent bedtime to creating a more conducive sleep environment. It's about experimenting with different approaches to find what works best for me.

Dimension: Following regular schedule for bedtime & sleeping enough
Statement: I find it very difficult to have a nice sleep. I can't fall asleep at night and I am always tired in the morning but I still couldn't sleep.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It feels like a vicious cycle where no matter how exhausted I am, I just can't seem to fall asleep at night. Then in the next morning, I'm too tired to function but still can't catch any rest. It's as if my body's clock is completely out of sync.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could there be underlying issues or habits contributing to this sleep dilemma that I haven't fully addressed? What steps can I take to break this cycle, even if they seem small or incremental at first?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Exploring a variety of sleep practices and possibly seeking advice from a professional could offer new solutions. Establishing a relaxing pre-sleep routine and ensuring my sleeping environment is optimized for rest could make a significant difference.

Dimension: Following regular schedule for bedtime & sleeping enough
Statement: I feel like I want to sleep too much. I feel tired during the day even when I had a long time to sleep. I can't control myself to keep wanting to sleep.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It seems like no matter how much I sleep, it's never enough. I'm constantly battling this overwhelming desire to sleep more, and it feels like my energy levels just aren't in my control.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is the quantity of sleep the real issue, or could the quality of my sleep be lacking? Are there factors in my lifestyle or health that I haven't considered that might be affecting my energy levels throughout the day?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Assessing my sleep quality and overall health might reveal insights into why I'm feeling this way. Making adjustments to my sleep environment, routine, or even consulting a healthcare professional could help in finding a more balanced approach to my sleep and energy levels.

Dimension: Following regular schedule for bedtime & sleeping enough
Statement: I feel like I want to sleep too much. I feel tired during the day even when I had a long time to sleep. I can't control myself to keep wanting to sleep.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It seems like no matter how much I sleep, it's never enough. I'm constantly battling this overwhelming desire to sleep more, and it feels like my energy levels just aren't in my control.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is the quantity of sleep the real issue, or could the quality of my sleep be lacking? Are there factors in my lifestyle or health that I haven't considered that might be affecting my energy levels throughout the day?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I think I can just find more time to sleep more.

Statement: I'm not eating regularly, especially for breakfast and lunch. I always skip them when  I'm busy.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I often think that skipping meals, particularly when I'm swamped, is a necessary sacrifice to manage my workload. It feels like there just aren't enough hours in the day to sit down and eat properly.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is skipping meals genuinely saving me time, or could it be impacting my productivity and energy levels negatively? Might there be a way to incorporate quick and nutritious meals into my busy schedule?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Planning ahead for busy days by preparing quick, healthy meals or snacks could help ensure I'm fueling my body adequately. Recognizing that nourishment is a crucial part of maintaining productivity might encourage me to prioritize meal times.

Statement: I eat whenever I can't stand the hunger, so I end up eating at very different times.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I feel like my eating habits are dictated by my hunger pangs, leading to irregular meal times. It seems like my schedule is too unpredictable to allow for structured meal times.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could this reactive approach to eating be less about my schedule's unpredictability and more about not prioritizing meal planning? Might there be a way to introduce some regularity into my eating habits, even with a fluctuating schedule?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Trying to establish a basic routine for meals, even if it's flexible, could help manage my hunger better and lead to more balanced eating habits.

Statement: I don't really eat much at all. I'm always feel full even after eating a little and feel disgusted to eat more.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It feels like my appetite is just naturally low, and trying to eat more than a little at a time turns me off completely. It's like my body just rejects the idea of food once I hit a certain point.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is this feeling of fullness a sign that I need to look more closely at my dietary habits or health? Could there be underlying factors affecting my appetite that I haven't considered?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Exploring smaller, more nutrient-dense meals might be a way to ensure I'm getting enough nutrition without feeling overwhelmed.

Statement: I don't really eat much at all. I'm always feel full even after eating a little and feel disgusted to eat more.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I just don't need to eat more than that.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Why would I eat more things when I am not hungry? I can also lose weight because I don't eat much.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Exploring smaller, more nutrient-dense meals might be a way to ensure I'm getting enough nutrition without feeling overwhelmed.

Statement: I eat way too much thing. I just can't stop.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It feels like once I start eating, I lose all control and just can't help but overeat. I don't feel full at the moment, but I can feel I ate too much afterwards.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is my overeating truly beyond my control, or are there triggers and habits contributing to this pattern that I can identify and address?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Seeking to understand the emotional or situational triggers that lead to overeating could help me develop healthier coping strategies. Introducing mindful eating practices, setting structured meal times might allow me to establish a more balanced approach to eating.

Statement: I skip a lot of school. It's so boring to be there.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): School just drags on with the same dull routine every day, making me feel like I'm not gaining anything by being there. It seems more appealing to just skip it and do things that actually interest me.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could this boredom be a sign that I need to engage more actively or find new ways to make the learning process more interesting for myself? Are there opportunities within school that I haven't explored yet that could make it more fulfilling?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Looking for aspects of school that align with my interests, such as clubs, sports, or specific subjects, might help make it more engaging. Communicating with teachers about my interests could also lead to more personalized learning opportunities.

Statement: I skip a lot of school. It's so boring to be there.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): School just drags on with the same dull routine every day, making me feel like I'm not gaining anything by being there. It seems more appealing to just skip it and do things that actually interest me.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Isn't most of what I learn in school going to be useless for me afterwards anyways?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Skipping school is fine. I can have the time to do much more things I like. I wish I didn't have to go.

Statement: I'm not showing up for work on time. I'm always tired out and feel so much pain when going to work.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Every morning feels like a battle just to get out of bed and face the day. The thought of going to work is so daunting that it physically hurts.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is the exhaustion and pain I'm feeling a sign of deeper issues, like burnout or health concerns, that I haven't fully addressed? What steps can I take to understand and mitigate these feelings?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Identifying the root causes of my tiredness and discomfort could lead to effective solutions, whether that's adjusting my workload, seeking medical advice, or finding strategies to improve my work-life balance.

Statement: I don't like to go to school at all. I'm not doing very well and I don't wanna face it.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): School just feels like a constant reminder of my struggles, and the idea of facing those challenges is overwhelming. It seems easier to avoid it altogether than to deal with the possibility of failure.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could avoiding school be worsening my academic challenges rather than alleviating them? What resources or support might I be missing out on by not facing the situation?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Seeking help and communicating about my difficulties could open up pathways for improvement I hadn't considered. There might be tutors, counseling, or study groups that can provide the support I need to overcome these hurdles and change my perspective on school.

Statement: I really depends on the day, but I might be not showing up too much. If I wake up and feel tired, then I'm more likely to not go.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): My attendance is decided by how I feel each morning. On days when I wake up feeling tired, it feels justified to skip, as if my energy levels dictate my ability to participate or be productive.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is my daily energy level the sole factor I should rely on for important commitments like school or work? Might there be ways to manage my energy more effectively or to motivate myself even on low-energy days?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Establishing a more consistent routine, possibly including better sleep and morning rituals, could help stabilize my energy levels. On days when I'm tired, I could use strategies to boost my motivation, like focusing on the positive impacts of showing up, such as learning something new or moving forward with my goals.

Statement: I have not taken any day off recently. I have class almost everyday and lots of work to do.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It feels like my schedule is non-stop, and taking a break just isn't an option. There's a constant pressure to keep pushing through, despite feeling run down and overwhelmed.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is continuously working without a break truly the most effective way to manage my responsibilities, or could it be diminishing my productivity and well-being over time? Might there be benefits to scheduling regular breaks that I'm overlooking?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Intentionally planning short breaks and time off could not only prevent burnout but also enhance my focus and efficiency in the long run. It's about finding a sustainable balance between work and rest.

Statement: I have not taken any day off recently. I have class almost everyday and lots of work to do.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I dont' deserve a break when I still got things to finish.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is continuously working without a break truly the most effective way to manage my responsibilities, or could it be diminishing my productivity and well-being over time? Might there be benefits to scheduling regular breaks that I'm overlooking?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Intentionally planning short breaks and time off could not only prevent burnout but also enhance my focus and efficiency in the long run. It's about finding a sustainable balance between work and rest.

Statement: I take only maybe a small fraction of a day to rest. There is too much going on and I feel like I don't have the time to stop and relax.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It seems like every moment of my day needs to be filled with productivity to keep up with everything. The idea of taking substantial time to relax feels almost like a luxury I can't afford, lest I fall behind.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could this constant push for productivity actually be counterproductive, perhaps leading to diminished quality of work and increased stress? How might my performance and well-being improve with more balanced rest periods?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Reevaluating my schedule to incorporate more meaningful rest could enhance my overall productivity and mental health. It might involve prioritizing tasks more effectively, setting clearer boundaries, or learning to be okay with taking necessary breaks for long-term sustainability.

Statement: The work life balance is horrible. I get no day off even on the weekends and that is really bothering me.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It's like, no matter what, there's always work piling up. It's just non-stop, and it's realistically impossible to find any time to rest.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is it really impossible to find some downtime, or am I just stuck in this cycle because that's how it's always been? What would happen if I actually scheduled a break for myself?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): What if I get fired? I need to work harder.

Dimension: Showing up for appointments and obligations
Statement: To be honest, I miss a lot of my appointments. Sometimes when I start doing something, I lose track of time and forget about other plans.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I get so caught up in whatever I'm doing that everything else just fades away. It's like, once I'm in the zone, I totally blank on anything else I had lined up.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could there be a better way to keep track of things? Like, maybe I'm not using reminders effectively, or I could be underestimating how much time tasks actually take.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Maybe setting up more alerts on my phone or using a planner could help keep me on track. And it might be worth trying to give myself a little buffer between tasks, so if I do get carried away, I've got some wiggle room.

Dimension: Showing up for appointments and obligations
Statement: I often miss my appointments. The idea of having an obligation to do something at a specific time just bothers me, and so I  run away from it.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It's like, the moment I know I have to be somewhere or do something at a certain time, I just want to bail. I don't know, it feels like being trapped or something, and I end up avoiding it altogether.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is it the commitment itself that's bugging me, or is it more about how I'm looking at these obligations? Maybe there's a way to view them differently, so they don't feel so constricting.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Perhaps I could start seeing these appointments as opportunities or even small wins in my day. And working on planning things in a way that feels more flexible might help me not want to dodge them so much.

Dimension: Showing up for appointments and obligations
Statement: I often miss my appointments. The idea of having an obligation to do something at a specific time just bothers me, and so I  run away from it.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It's like, the moment I know I have to be somewhere or do something at a certain time, I just want to bail. I don't know, it feels like being trapped or something, and I end up avoiding it altogether.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is it the commitment itself that's bugging me, or is it more about how I'm looking at these obligations? Maybe there's a way to view them differently, so they don't feel so constricting.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I can just make less appointments. This way I avoid it from the beginning.

Dimension: Showing up for appointments and obligations
Statement: I can't show up or do every obligation. I feel like everything urges me at the same time and I just have too much going on.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It's like, everywhere I turn, there's something else demanding my attention. It feels like I'm being pulled in a million directions. It's overwhelming, and I end up dropping the ball because it's just too much.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is it really that everything is urgent, or am I having a hard time setting priorities? Maybe there's a way to sort through all this stuff and figure out what needs my focus first.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Taking a step back and laying everything out might help. Like, if I can see what's on my plate and decide what's really urgent and what can wait, maybe things won't feel so chaotic.

Dimension: Managing finance and items of value
Statement: I feel likely I might be spending to much lately. Rent is crazy and there are too many things that I feel are necessary to buy.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It just seems like my money's flying out the window these days. Between the sky-high rent and all these things I think I gotta have, my wallet's taking a hit. It's like, how do I even keep up?
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is everything I'm buying really a must-have, or could I be mixing up wants with needs? Maybe there's a way to dial it back a bit without feeling like I'm missing out.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Taking a closer look at where my cash is going could be helpful. Maybe setting a budget for those necessary buys could help keep things in check.

Dimension: Managing finance and items of value
Statement: I am spending a lot, probably more than I have too. I often lose track of how much I spend even when I don't buy really expensive stuff.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Even without big purchases, my spending just seems to spiral. Keeping track on where my money goes feels overwhelming, and I always thought buying small things isn't a big deal.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Am I really paying attention to all those smaller expenses? Maybe they're piling up more than I realize. Could keeping a closer eye on these help me get a handle on my spending?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Tracking every expense, big or small, could show where I can cut back. Setting a budget for different categories of spending might help me control where my money is going without having to drastically change my lifestyle.

Dimension: Managing finance and items of value
Statement: I almost buy nothing and I thinks its problematic now. I only buy things when I think its necessary, but I've had many times when I regret not getting something that I actually needed.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I'm so cautious with my spending that I often pass up things I need, telling myself they're not essential. Then, I end up in situations where I regret not making the purchase.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could my strict rules on what's necessary be too rigid, leading me to miss out on things that could genuinely improve my life or solve a problem?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Maybe I need to redefine what necessary means to me, allowing a bit more flexibility.

Statement: I am not eating healthy at all. I hate to eat vegetables. The taste of it is just unbearable for me.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I just can't stand veggies, and that makes eating healthy seem impossible. Every time I try, the taste just turns me off completely.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is it all vegetables I dislike, or have I just not found the right ones or the right ways to prepare them? Could there be recipes out there that make them more palatable?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Maybe I could experiment with different cooking methods or recipes that disguise or enhance the taste of vegetables.

Statement: I definitely need to eat more healthy and nutritious stuff. I don't have much time or skills to cook. That's why I eat outside a lot and most of the foods are oily and calorie.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I'm stuck eating out because I'm short on time and cooking skills.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could there be quicker, healthier meal options that I haven't explored yet? Maybe I'm overestimating the time and skill needed to prepare something nutritious.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Exploring simple, healthy recipes that require minimal time and skill could be the solution. There might also be healthier takeout options that I haven't considered yet, which could help balance convenience with nutrition.

Statement: I definitely need to eat more healthy and nutritious stuff. I don't have much time or skills to cook. That's why I eat outside a lot and most of the foods are oily and calorie.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I'm stuck eating out because I'm short on time and cooking skills.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could there be quicker, healthier meal options that I haven't explored yet? Maybe I'm overestimating the time and skill needed to prepare something nutritious.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Learning how to cook healthy meal takes too much effort. I can hold on for a few years eating unhealthy food because I'm still young.

Statement: I've been going on a pretty strick vegetarian diet, but I think my body is not responding well. I wanted to lose weight and become healthier, but I started to feel sick after going into this diet.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I jumped into this vegetarian diet hoping for positive changes, but now I'm just feeling worse. It's like my body's rejecting this new way of eating, even though I thought it was supposed to be healthier.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is my vegetarian diet well-balanced, or could I be missing out on essential nutrients? Maybe the issue isn't the diet itself but how I'm approaching it.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Reevaluating my diet with a nutritionist or doing more research could help me adjust it to better suit my body's needs. There are other ways to lose weight that does not require such a strict diet.

Dimension: Problem solving and decision making capability
Statement: I am terrible at making decisions. I've always had someone take care of things for me, but now I'm living alone and having trouble to decide what needs to be done.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Making decisions is just not my strong suit. I used to have others make them for me, and now that I'm on my own, it feels like I'm just naturally not good at it.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could it be that I'm not used to making decisions, rather than not being capable of it? What small steps can I take to become more confident in my decision-making abilities?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Starting with smaller, less impactful decisions could help build my confidence. It's also okay to ask for advice or do a bit of research when I'm unsure, as long as I'm gradually taking more of these decisions into my own hands.

Dimension: Problem solving and decision making capability
Statement: I always need a long time to make decisions. When I have a choice to make, I often can't determine which is better than the other, and I also cannot just decide on one and see what happens, so I get stuck.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I overthink the options to the point where I can't pick one. It feels safer to not choose at all than to make the wrong decision.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is there really a wrong decision, or are most choices just different paths with their own sets of pros and cons? What's the worst that could happen if I make a decision and it's not perfect?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Maybe I could try giving myself permission to make good enough decisions instead of perfect ones. Setting a time limit for decision-making might also help me move forward without getting too bogged down.

Dimension: Problem solving and decision making capability
Statement: I'm bad at solving tough problem that has a lot of stakes to consider. When I encounter such a problem, I panic and lose focus.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Every time I hit a big, complicated problem, I just fall apart. The pressure of getting it right because it's so important just overwhelms me, and I can't think straight.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is the panic really about the problem itself, or is it more about how I'm approaching it? Maybe breaking it down into smaller, more manageable parts could help me tackle it without getting overwhelmed.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Approaching these problems step by step might make them feel less daunting. And reminding myself that it's okay to ask for help or take a break when I'm feeling stuck could help keep the panic at bay and maintain focus.

Dimension: Problem solving and decision making capability
Statement: I'm bad at solving tough problem that has a lot of stakes to consider. When I encounter such a problem, I panic and lose focus.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Every time I hit a big, complicated problem, I just fall apart. The pressure of getting it right because it's so important just overwhelms me, and I can't think straight.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is the panic really about the problem itself, or is it more about how I'm approaching it? Maybe breaking it down into smaller, more manageable parts could help me tackle it without getting overwhelmed.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Alternatively, I can just avoid having to deal with tough problems.

Statement: I am not supported by my family. I seem to always want to do things that's against what my family wants, so I feel disconnected with them.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It feels like my family and I are just on different wavelengths. Every time I want to pursue something, it's like hitting a wall with them.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could there be a way to communicate my goals and desires to my family in a way that they might understand better? Is there a middle ground where we can respect our differences but still find some common support?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Maybe I need to find support in other places, like friends or communities with similar interests.

Statement: I don't know. I like to keep everything to my self so I barely talk to them. I don't know if they will support me and I'm  hesitant to find out.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I've always kept things close to my chest, thinking it's easier that way. It's like I'm stuck in my own head with these worries.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could my assumption that they won't understand or support me be based more on fear than reality? What might happen if I took a small step to share something with them?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Finding a casual way to start communicating more with my family could help test the waters. It doesn't have to be all or nothing. I can share small things and see how it goes, building up to more personal topics as I feel more comfortable.

Statement: My family does not support me. They don't like my job and we are barely seeing each other.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): We hardly spend any time together, and I can feel the disapproval hanging in the air every time my work comes up. It's like we're drifting apart.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is the distance between us solely because of my job, or could there be other underlying issues? What steps could I take to address this divide, even if they don't agree with my career?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Maybe I could try to find some common ground outside of work or initiate conversations to express how this rift is affecting me. It might also be helpful to seek understanding and find ways to connect that don't involve my job.

Statement: My family does not support me. They don't like my job and we are barely seeing each other.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): We hardly spend any time together, and I can feel the disapproval hanging in the air every time my work comes up. It's like we're drifting apart.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is the distance between us solely because of my job, or could there be other underlying issues? What steps could I take to address this divide, even if they don't agree with my career?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): It's my family's problem for not understanding my choices. I can just move on without them.

Statement: My relationship with my family members is not too well. My parents always fights and I moved out as soon as I could.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Growing up in a house where there was always tension has really strained my connection with my family. Moving out was my way of escaping that.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is the distance from my family solely a result of the conflicts, or are there ways I can build individual relationships with them despite the past?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Perhaps reaching out to my family members individually could help mend some of those strained relationships, focusing on positive interactions. It's about finding a new way to connect that isn't overshadowed by past conflicts.

Statement: I feel like I'm not too close to my family anymore. I am very busy at work and often forget to contact them or meet them.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): With all the demands of work, it's like my family has just slipped to the back burner. I barely reach out, and the gap just keeps growing.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is my busy schedule the only reason for the growing distance, or could I find small ways to stay connected even amidst the chaos? Maybe there are simple, quick methods of communication I haven't considered.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Setting reminders to check in with my family or scheduling regular catch-ups, even if they're brief, could help bridge the gap. It's about making those small efforts consistently to maintain the bond, even when life gets hectic.

Statement: I feel like I'm not too close to my family anymore. I am very busy at work and often forget to contact them or meet them.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): With all the demands of work, it's like my family has just slipped to the back burner. I barely reach out, and the gap just keeps growing.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is my busy schedule the only reason for the growing distance, or could I find small ways to stay connected even amidst the chaos? Maybe there are simple, quick methods of communication I haven't considered.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I will stick to my work for now. Maybe eventually there will be sometime in the future where I'm less busy.

Statement: I am not a very emotional person, so I don't feel like I have a strong connection with my family. Honestly, I don't feel a strong connection with anyone.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Being less emotional makes me feel disconnected from my family and others. It's like there's a barrier I can't cross, making it hard to form deep bonds.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is emotional expressiveness the only way to connect with others, or could there be different ways to build strong relationships that align with my personality?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Maybe I can find alternative ways to show I care and connect with people that don't necessarily require overt emotional expressions. It could be through shared activities, thoughtful gestures, or just being present and reliable in their lives.

Statement: I often drink alone and a lot. When I get stressed, I like to drink alcohol to temprorarily forget about what I need to do.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Whenever stress piles up, it feels like alcohol is my only escape. It's like a quick fix that lets me push all those worries aside, even if it's just for a little while.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is relying on alcohol to cope with stress really helping, or is it just a temporary band-aid that might be causing more issues in the long run? What healthier coping mechanisms could I explore?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Finding healthier stress relief methods, like exercise, hobbies, or talking to someone, could offer a more sustainable way to manage stress without the downsides of alcohol.

Statement: I think I'm drinking too much and my body is getting worse. I just love the taste of it and the feeling of getting drunk.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I'm caught up in how good it feels to drink and the escape it provides, but I can't ignore the toll it's taking on my health. It's like I'm stuck between wanting that feeling and knowing it's harming me.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Could there be a way to enjoy the aspects I like about drinking in moderation, or find alternative activities that provide a similar sense of enjoyment without the negative health effects?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Exploring hobbies or interests that bring me joy and relaxation might help reduce my reliance on alcohol for pleasure. It could be about finding balance and healthier ways to cope and unwind.

Statement: I can't live without alcohol. I need it to relax and sleep at night.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): It's like I've become dependent on alcohol to wind down and sleep. Without it, I feel anxious and restless.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is there a way to address the underlying reasons for my anxiety and sleep issues, rather than relying solely on alcohol? Could there be healthier relaxation and sleep strategies I haven't explored?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Exploring relaxation techniques, such as meditation or deep breathing exercises, might provide an alternative way to unwind and improve sleep. It's about finding a sustainable path to relaxation and rest without relying on alcohol.

Statement: I often drink alone and a lot. When I get stressed, I like to drink alcohol to temprorarily forget about what I need to do.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): Other people drink alcohol to relax too. It's fine if I do the same.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Is relying on alcohol to cope with stress really helping, or is it just a temporary band-aid that might be causing more issues in the long run? What healthier coping mechanisms could I explore?
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Finding other methods seems to be too much work. At least I can still somewhat function right now.

Statement: I don't smoke cigarettes, but I vape every day. I vape when I am working hard or debugging.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): My unhelpful thoughts might be vaping is the only way I can relieve stress or concentrate while working.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Sometimes vaping doesn't help with my concentration during work or efficiency while I am debugging. There are long-term harm to health if I vape a lot as well.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Although I often rely on vaping to manage stress and enhance concentration, it's not the only method available to me. In fact, sometimes vaping doesn't actually improve my concentration or efficiency. There are also long-term health risks associated with frequent vaping. I can explore other healthier stress management and focus-enhancing techniques that are beneficial for both my mental and physical well-being.

Statement: I don't smoke cigarettes, but I vape every day. I vape when I am working hard or debugging.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I cant work or solve problems effectively without vaping
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): There are several potential health impacts of vaping. It's bad for my lung.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Vaping is unhealthy. But I need vaping to concentrate and work to make a living.

Statement: I don't smoke cigarettes, but I vape every day. I vape when I am working hard or debugging.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I think I vape because I enjoy the flavors, and it's just a harmless habit.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): I should stop vaping immediately. Other people can manage stress without vaping, so I should be able to as well.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Since vaping is bad and others dont need it, I must stop it right now to prove that I can handle work and stress like everyone else.

Statement: I smoke at most 10 cigarettes per day. I smoke because some of my colleagues also smoke in between work. So I just join them.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I smoke cigarettes because my colleagues smoke and I want to join them.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): There might be other healthier ways I can hangout with my colleagues.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I might be able to stop smoking as I leverage the smoking break as the time to hang out with my colleagues.

Statement: I smoke at most 10 cigarettes per day. I smoke because some of my colleagues also smoke in between work. So I just join them.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I smoke because I like the taste of cigarettes, and it gives me something to do during breaks.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): There might be other healthier ways I can hangout with my colleagues and taking breaks.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I might be able to stop smoking as I leverage the smoking break as the time to hang out with my colleagues.

Statement: I smoke weed a few times a week alone. I need to take some weed to help me get inspirations for my work.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I smoke weed because it's the only way I can relax and unwind. Without it, I can't cope with the stress of my day-to-day life.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): There are sometimes I get inspiration and feel good after I hangout with my friends in a jazz bar.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): While I've often used weed as a tool for inspiration and relaxation for my work, I recognize that it's not my only option. There have been times when I've found inspiration and felt good in other settings, like when I hang out with friends at a jazz bar. This suggests that my creativity and relaxation aren't solely dependent on smoking weed.

Statement: I smoke weed a few times a week alone. I need to take some weed to help me get inspirations for my work.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I smoke weed to get inspiration for my work.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Somking weed does not always bring me inspirations. Sometimes it gets me depressed instead.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I have believed that smoking weed is essential for finding inspiration for my work, but I've realized this isn't always the case. In fact, sometimes it can have the opposite effect, leaving me feeling depressed rather than inspired. This recognition opens up the possibility that inspiration can come from other sources and activities, ones that don't have negative side effects on my mood. I can explore alternative ways to stimulate my creativity, such as engaging in different types of brainstorming activities, seeking new experiences, or drawing inspiration from nature, books, or art.

Statement: I smoke weed a few times a week alone. I need to take some weed to help me get inspirations for my work.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I smoke weed to get inspiration for my work.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Somking weed does not always bring me inspirations. Sometimes it gets me depressed instead.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): Smoking weed not always provide me inspiration. But I just love weed. I love to get inspiration from weed.

Statement: Every evening, after a long day of work, I feel mentally drained and anxious about the next day. To relax and escape these feelings, I've begun to drink alcohol or occasionally use prescription drugs alone at home. It started as a way to take the edge off after particularly tough days, but now it has become a routine.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): The only way I can cope with the stress and pressure from my job is by using substances.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Use the substances and drink will harm my health in the long term.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): While they seem to offer temporary relief, I understand that there are healthier ways to manage my stress. I can explore stress reduction techniques such as running. There are a few running clubs in my area. It might be good to join in one and start to socialize myself with others as well.

Dimension: Enjoying personal choices for leisure activities:
Statement: I don't have too much personal leisure time recently. I am too busy with upcoming deadlines in school.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): The upcoming deadlines compromise my personal leisure time.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): Sometimes I when I work for my deadlines, I am not efficient.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): I could convert the less-efficient time period to some short segments of personal leisure time and enjoy some activities I like. Such as running and hiking.

Dimension: Enjoying personal choices for leisure activities:
Statement: I'm currently a PhD student in electric engineering, deeply immersed in my research. My days are filled with experiments, data analysis, and writing academic papers. When I'm not working on my research, I find myself without any clear idea of what to do for leisure. My social circle has become quite limited, mostly consisting of fellow researchers and academics, and our conversations often circle back to work and studies. And I will feel guilty if I really spend time on my hobbies, like watching movies and go shopping.
Unhelpful Thoughts (CBT_Stage1): I have no idea for what should I do for my leisure time.
Challenge (CBT_Stage2): If I push myself into social events or start a new hobby immediately, I'll stop feeling this way.
Another Way (CBT_Stage3): To fix this situation, I will start doing a variety of random activities and hobbies immediately. I should start to try to go to the gym with my labmates. They seem to go to gym every other day.
